When Zachary reached for Evelyn, Adrian twisted away.

"Get a car ready if you want her to live!" Adrian barked.

Zachary sneered. "You stabbed her. Don't play the hero now."

Pain lanced through Adrian's chest, but he only held Evelyn closer. No other man would touch her.

###Chapter 139

Zachary Deross grabbed Adrian Valentine by the collar and dragged him toward the underground parking lot.

#AdrianValentineStabsEvelynForIsabella

###Chapter 140

###Chapter 141

This child was usually so shy around strangers—why was she so attached to Adrian?

Sophia was the little princess of Sterling Manor. She had nothing to do with the Valentines!

Once Sophia turned three, she would begin specialized training. Even they would hardly get to see her then.

###Chapter 142

Adrian Valentine stared at his empty arms, feeling as if a piece of his heart had been carved out.

The little girl's departure left him with an inexplicable sense of loss.

He composed himself and followed Nathan Aldridge and Zachary Deross toward the hospital room.

Evelyn Roland lay motionless on the bed, an oxygen mask covering half her face. The heart monitor beeped sharply.

How much pain had she endured when she hurt herself?

On their last mission before the divorce, she had taken a bullet for him without hesitation.

A man who betrays love has no integrity.

Did they think he was deaf?

"Are you threatening Adrian?" Eleanor cut him off with a cold laugh. "He fell for Isabella at first sight. He tossed Evelyn aside like trash. Your idea is idiotic."
###Chapter 170

Jonathan Savigny couldn't shake the feeling that something was off.

But Adrian Valentine had been separated from Isabella for over a year now. Maybe he was overthinking it.

"I heard Adrian recently secured a multi-billion-dollar eco-resort project," Jonathan remarked casually.

Eleanor Langley rose gracefully. "It's too early to discuss partnerships. I should head back. You handle the press release—I might lose my composure in the car."

She forced herself to stay composed.

Jonathan smirked knowingly.

Eleanor shot him a glare.

"The site borders Sterling Manor. They'll be co-developing," he added.

"This could be a lucrative opportunity for our company."

He wrapped his arms around her from behind, resting his chin on her shoulder. "Stay tonight. Vincent will be up all night studying those maps."

"Still not satisfied?" His voice dropped to a husky murmur.

Eleanor's cheeks flushed. "The villa, then. But I must return before dawn. Release the statement first."

Jonathan's grin widened. "Agreed."

——

Evelyn Roland arrived home to find her twins playing on the playmat.

Her grandfather had dropped them off early after visiting friends.

"Mommy!"

Felicia scrambled toward her, giggling. Tristan waved quietly.

"Gabrielle's here," Evelyn noted, spotting the open medical journal.

She dropped her bag and swept both children into a fierce embrace, covering them with kisses.

"What are you researching now?" She nodded at the notebook.

Gabrielle Flores held it up. "I'm documenting cognitive differences between gifted infants and neurotypical children."

These two surpassed even Evelyn's IQ levels.

The elder twin exhibited startling analytical precision.

Felicia, though brilliant, had boundless energy—even in sleep.

Her intense focus and rapid reactions could shake the roof during playtime.

"How so?" Evelyn asked, equal parts hopeful and apprehensive.
###Chapter 171

Gabrielle's eyes sparkled as she spoke of this.

She flipped open her notebook with practiced ease, words tumbling out in excitement. "Evelyn, their memory is just like yours—photographic. When I taught them colors, they remembered instantly. Next time they saw black and red, both Ethan and Sophia pointed correctly without hesitation."

"Their observation skills are exceptional too. Ethan fixates on black toys, while Sophia waves her arms wildly at anything red."

"But their reasoning ability?" Gabrielle raised a finger triumphantly. "I showed them a puzzle twice. The third time? They turned away—already mastered it."

Evelyn paused while wiping Sophia's drool. "That impressive?"

"Wait, there's more." Gabrielle leaned in. "Their focus is terrifyingly strong—exactly like you as a child. Oh, and the curiosity! Remember how you grilled everyone about roosters and hens—"

Evelyn's ears burned. "Must you bring up ancient history?"

Gabrielle muffled a laugh. "Because the whole family was in stitches while you deadpanned those questions."

"Focus." Evelyn squeezed her daughter's plump hand. "Are you saying they'll surpass me?"

"Beyond that." Gabrielle shook her head. "Natural talent needs nurturing. Their genes are superior, plus my months of conditioning—their physical development outpaces peers."

A premonition of dethronement prickled Evelyn.

Right on cue, Gabrielle declared: "The smartest Roland is about to be dethroned!"

Sophia chose that moment to smack Evelyn's cheek with a soft "Mwah!"

"Darling?" Evelyn looked down.

Her daughter puckered up, planting a sloppy kiss.

"Adorable!" Evelyn melted, showering the baby with kisses.

Not to be outdone, Ethan yanked her shoulder demanding equal attention.

"Alright, alright." Evelyn alternated kisses, heart swelling.

Gabrielle watched sourly. "You should marvel at their genius, not just cuteness."

"Speaking of," she added seriously, "your birth parents must have remarkable genes. You always outpaced everyone effortlessly—our idol growing up."

Evelyn wiped Ethan's saliva off her face. "Nonsense. Your medical skills long surpassed mine."

"Never you." Gabrielle reached for the twins. "Go shower. I'll play with them."

Both babies squirmed toward Evelyn, faces scrunching in protest.

Gabrielle pouted. "After all my care..."

Laughing, Evelyn headed to the bathroom. These two kept her too busy for thoughts of Adrian Valentine.

Men? She had far greater priorities now.
###Chapter 172

Time could heal all wounds—except for Adrian Valentine. He remained the unhealed scar etched deep in her heart.

The sound of running water in the bathroom ceased.

Evelyn stepped out, drying her damp hair.

At half past nine, the clock chimed, signaling bedtime for the children.

After seeing Gabrielle off, she had tucked them in alone.

The little ones drifted into sleep effortlessly, but rest eluded her.

Tonight's unexpected encounter with Adrian was a thorn lodged in her chest.

Moonlight streamed through the window, casting a pale glow across the ceiling. She stared blankly at it.

The memory of his domineering kiss resurfaced, twisting her stomach with disgust and hatred.

His betrayal had been a blunt knife, carving into her heart inch by excruciating inch.

"Haah..." She forced herself to stop dwelling on it.

Her phone buzzed abruptly.

A message from Nathan: [Sis, check the news.]

Frowning, she tapped open the trending headlines.

[Evelyn Roland, Aldridge Group Assistant, Caught Seducing Adrian Valentine, CEO of Valentine Corp]

Accompanying the article was a crystal-clear photo of Adrian dragging her into the private room.

The comments section had exploded.

[So Isabella was framed. This woman has no shame.]

[Homewrecker! How dare she compete with my goddess?]

[Trash like her should get out of Vienna!]

Her fingers turned icy. Without hesitation, she dialed Adrian's number.

Adrian lay in their former marital home.

Since Evelyn left, sleep had abandoned him.

He had just closed his eyes on the couch when the jarring ringtone shattered the silence.

An unknown number flashed on the screen. Compelled by some unseen force, he answered.

"Adrian Valentine." Evelyn's voice was laced with frost. "Was tonight's spectacle just to whitewash Isabella's reputation?"

He bolted upright.

Her call was unexpected—but her accusation even more so.

"Believe what you want," he replied, his tone dangerously languid.

Her chest tightened.

What sin had she committed in a past life to deserve this?

"Do you really need to drive me into a corner?" Her nails dug into her palms.

Adrian chuckled darkly. "My demand is simple—disappear forever." His knuckles whitened. "Evelyn, if you dare lay a finger on Isabella, I won't hesitate to eliminate you myself."

That cryptic "I'm very good at killing" left her bewildered.

But the divorce was final. She should have let go long ago.

Drawing a shaky breath, she asked the question she already knew the answer to—knowing it would only wound her further.

"Adrian," her voice trembled, "even if it was all just a game to you... must you be so merciless?"
###Chapter 173

Adrian Valentine had just stepped off the plane when Evelyn Roland's call came through. His finger hovered over the screen for a fraction too long.

"Evelyn, what's left between us besides hatred?" His voice was gravelly with exhaustion.

"Tomorrow I'll release evidence of Isabella's contract killing." Her tone was eerily calm.

The floor lamp cast amber light over the unchanged living room. This time last year, Evelyn had curled on this very couch reading scripts, her hair spilling across his palm.

Memories flooded him—the flutter of her lashes when she stood on tiptoe to kiss him, the blush creeping up her ears as she whispered endearments, the faint teeth marks she left on his shoulder when angry.

Adrian downed a burning gulp of whiskey. The alcohol scorched his throat but couldn't extinguish the fire in his chest.

Evelyn had loved Alexander Durand. That truth burned fiercer than any liquor, charring him from the inside out.
###Chapter 174

Isabella Langley slammed her phone onto the couch.

She stared at the darkened screen, her chest heaving.

Adrian Valentine had hung up on her again.

Ever since Evelyn Roland reappeared, Adrian had grown increasingly distant.

Their marriage, a picture of perfection to outsiders, was crumbling from within.

The photos circulating online fueled her rage.

Adrian had publicly held Evelyn's hand.

Warren Garten entered still damp from his shower.

His gray robe hung loosely around his waist, revealing a toned chest.

At thirty-five, the man exuded mature magnetism.

Isabella's gaze lingered on him for a beat too long.

"Open this," she ordered, gesturing to the wine.

Warren picked up the corkscrew, his slender fingers working deftly.

"Because of the trending scandal?" His voice was husky.

She hadn't considered the danger of being alone with him this late.

"Isabella," he murmured.

"My father's collection never disappoints." She narrowed her eyes. "Evelyn knows about that incident."

Warren's hands stilled.

He drained his glass, his gaze burning into her.

"Don't worry." He stepped closer, his arm snaking around her waist. "She won't get the chance to talk."

Isabella melted into his embrace.

"Warren," she whispered, venom dripping from her words, "I want Evelyn Roland dead."
###Chapter 175

"Isabella, opportunities always come." His slender fingers lifted her chin, his voice a low murmur. "Do you really love Adrian that much?"

Without hesitation, she nodded. "He's the most captivating man I've ever met. I want no one else."

She remembered the first time she saw Adrian—standing bathed in sunlight, one glance was all it took to fall for him. Later, with some behind-the-scenes help, she finally got close to him.

A shadow flickered in Warren's eyes. That enigmatic man didn't deserve Isabella.

He leaned in, his breath hot against her ear.

Isabella shivered, her voice trembling. "Warren, what are you doing?"

Her eyes held conflicted emotions—fear and anticipation intertwined.

She clenched her fists, biting her lip. "No..."

"Every time we're in the car together, your scent drives me wild." He pulled her into his arms, burying his face in the curve of her neck.

Her body went weak, melting against him.

Warren smiled in satisfaction. Her resistance was paper-thin.

"I'm Adrian's woman. How dare you touch me?" she protested coyly.

His eyes darkened as his fingers wandered. "Little temptress."

He captured her lips in a kiss, and she half-heartedly reciprocated.

The desire of a mature man ignited instantly.

He was ecstatic. After a year of waiting, he finally had her.

Seeing her pliant submission, his last shred of restraint vanished.

The sound of tearing fabric pierced the silent room...

The next morning, Evelyn was preparing breakfast for her two children when Nathan called, asking about the online PR strategy.

Only then did she remember her interrupted call with Adrian the night before. She picked up a dumpling and replied calmly, "Release the footage of Isabella hiring a hitman."

It was the plan she and Adrian had agreed on.

"Understood." Nathan was about to hang up when Isabella's call flashed on Evelyn's screen.

###Chapter 176

Valentine Group CEO's Office.

His deep voice carried a hypnotic edge.

She'd called her mother an idiot at breakfast when she found out.

Adrian's captivating peach-blossom eyes narrowed, frost flashing in their depths.

This family was truly revolting.

She had to witness the spectacle.

Silence.

###Chapter 177

###Chapter 178

Evelyn arrived at C.Y Media headquarters.

###Chapter 179

Most employees in this building had been bribed by her.

###Chapter 180

Without a word, he yanked her into the emergency stairwell.

"Let go!" She struggled.

Adrian pinned her against the wall, gaze burning. "Evelyn? Or should I say, Tru?"

His laugh was icy. "Even your name was a lie. What else is fake?"

The last words were ground out between clenched teeth.
###Chapter 184

Evelyn frowned slightly, studying Adrian's agitated expression. He must have overheard their conversation.

A bitter taste rose in her throat.

Adrian, my love for you was real.

But it meant nothing to you.

"Adrian, whoever I am, our marriage is over," she said calmly. "Evelyn Roland was the name the Langley family gave me."

"I've been using it all these years to investigate Alexander's case."

She chose honesty.

Adrian's Adam's apple bobbed as he rasped, "What's your real name?"

"Evelyn Roland," she whispered.

A cold laugh escaped him, danger flashing in his eyes. "Even your name was a lie. How many more secrets are you hiding?"

"Did you only marry me to investigate Alexander Durand?"

His voice dropped to subzero temperatures.

Evelyn shook her head, gaze steady. "No. These four years, I just wanted to live peacefully. If I'd wanted to use you, you'd have noticed."

"Let the past stay buried."

She turned to leave, pain threatening to spill from her eyes.

Unrequited love hurt too much.

Adrian narrowed his piercing gaze.

Sunlight outlined his perfect profile but couldn't penetrate the shadows in his eyes.

"Evelyn, you lied about everything. How could you say you loved me without blinking?"

He'd heard every word—Alexander was her brother.

That raw grief in her eyes whenever she mentioned him... she probably didn't even recognize it herself.

Evelyn paused mid-step but said nothing, striding toward the elevator.

......

After shopping with Scarlett, Evelyn returned to Sterling Manor to nurse her baby before heading to the Imperial Palace Hotel.

This was where Adrian used to bring her.

She knew his private dining room. With no one cooking at the Valentine estate now, he likely dined here often.

To avoid him, she took the side entrance.

The deserted lobby should have been safe—until she collided with Julian Roscente.

Evelyn suppressed a sigh. Why did she keep running into people she wanted to avoid?

"Evelyn, here for dinner?" Julian approached eagerly.

She retreated half a step. "Meeting friends. Excuse me."

His eyes trailed over her stylish outfit. Since leaving Adrian, her fashion sense had become impeccable.

"Vincent Ashcroft is back tonight. Join us? You know him."

Her expression frosted over at the name. "No need. I wouldn't want to lower the tone of Mr. Ashcroft's welcome party."

Those cruel words from years ago still stung.

A mocking voice cut in from behind: "Well, well. Evelyn Roland learns humility after all these years?"
###Chapter 185

Evelyn Roland cast an icy glance at Vincent Ashcroft's excessively handsome face.

This man excelled at putting on pretenses.

Outwardly charming and suave.

But beneath that facade lurked a cunning, treacherous nature—like a dagger hidden behind a smile, as the old saying went.

She knew Adrian Valentine's inner circle well.

Each had their own agenda. Christian Lefèvre was Adrian's most loyal friend, their bond forged through life-and-death trials.

Not once had they clashed in all these years.

During the divorce, she'd assumed Adrian was grieving Christian's death.

Only later did she realize he'd met his true love—Isabella Langley.

Before slipping into a coma, Christian had sworn her to secrecy about his survival. There was clearly more to the story. She'd been preoccupied with childbirth this past year, unable to investigate.

Now it seemed she needed to look into Christian's affairs.

Isabella and Adrian had arrived with Vincent.

Evelyn's gaze collided with Adrian's. She looked away indifferently.

A glacial glint flashed in Adrian's eyes, sharp as a blade.

Julian Roscente glared at Vincent, brows furrowed. "Vincent, that was uncalled for. I invited Evelyn here. If you disapprove, say so directly—no need for such venom."

Vincent gaped at Julian. "Julian Roscente, I've been gone a year, and you've changed. Weren't you the one who used to sneer at Evelyn, that country girl who only knew how to seduce men? What's this sudden closeness? Has she ensnared you too?"

"Julian, this isn't how brothers treat each other. That woman is Adrian's castoff. Someone gentle and virtuous like Isabella is far more suited to him."

As for Evelyn...

An unattainable alpine rose, born to lowly origins, forever wearing that frigid expression.

The sight of her disgusted him.

Julian's voice turned thunderous. "Vincent, you—"

Didn't he realize how cruel those words were?

These spoiled heirs loved gossiping about others. He suddenly felt sick of himself.

Evelyn gave Vincent a cool once-over. "Vincent, there's a difference between having a foul mouth and lacking basic decency."

"Also, my origins are none of your concern. My life isn't yours to dictate. The Ashcrofts are mere second-tier aristocrats—wealthy but morally bankrupt. You've looked down on me from the start, treating me as your plaything. I won't forget this... hospitality."

With that icy retort, she turned on her heel just as the elevator arrived.

Julian hurried after her.

Evelyn's eyes turned arctic. "Get lost."

Julian froze. Her gaze held a murderous edge he'd never seen before. She blocked the elevator doors. "Evelyn, I—"

Isabella watched Julian chase after Evelyn, jealousy twisting her insides.

Julian used to orbit around her.

She'd never allow Evelyn to steal what was rightfully hers.

She stepped forward. "Julian, you can't possibly fancy Evelyn? You're Adrian's friend. If you pursue his ex—"

"Isabella, watch your tongue. I'm pursuing Evelyn of my own volition. Adrian divorced her—what ties remain between them?"

"Besides, what gives you the right to meddle in my affairs?"

After delivering this scathing rebuke, Julian entered the elevator.

Isabella burned with humiliation. Never had Julian treated her this way.

"Adrian..."

Adrian shot her a frosty glance. She immediately fell silent.
###Chapter 186

Evelyn's eyes widened as she stared at Julian. "You want to pursue me?"

Julian scratched his head, his ears turning slightly pink. "Evelyn, could you give me a chance?"

A sudden chill crept up his back before he finished speaking.

Adrian had appeared behind him without warning.

Isabella and Vincent followed them into the elevator.

Evelyn's voice was icy. "Sorry, I have a blind date to attend."

Everyone connected to Adrian had once looked down on her.

Her gaze swept past Isabella, recalling what she'd witnessed downstairs that morning.

That receptionist turned out to be Isabella's pawn.

Evelyn smirked. "What do they have to do with me?"

The elevator doors opened. Evelyn strode out without looking back.

Silence filled the elevator.

Julian laughed bitterly. "So our careless words were just rubbing salt in her wounds."

Shaking his head, he exited the elevator with long strides.

His family's business had been struggling lately. Potential partners refused meetings upon hearing his playboy reputation.

Now he finally understood how Evelyn felt.

Vincent scoffed. "Julian's changed."

Adrian remained expressionless. "Let's go."

Isabella discreetly texted Cassandra.

By coincidence, Adrian's private room was next to Evelyn's.

Dressed in white, he exuded warmth and refinement.

His delicate features softened with a spring-like smile.

"Sebastian!" Evelyn's eyes curved with joy.

He studied her carefully. "Evelyn, you've grown even more beautiful in five years."

"How have you been abroad?" Her tone brightened.

"Quite well. Come in—I ordered your favorite dishes."

Sebastian naturally took her hand, oblivious to Adrian's group nearby.

Julian stood frozen, his face stricken. "She really came for a blind date!"
###Chapter 187

Adrian Valentine's gaze locked onto Evelyn Roland's direction.

He suddenly realized how long it had been since he last saw her cunning smile.

To outsiders, she was ice-cold.

Only in front of him did she reveal her childlike innocence.

Yet she had never shared the pain in her heart.

Throughout their relationship, she had always worn a mask.

Even when she was responsible for Christian Lefèvre's death.

He had never spoken of it to anyone.

All he wanted was for her to live well.

But watching her prepare to marry another man.

Jealousy was driving him mad.

Isabella Langley noticed Adrian's tension immediately.

"Adrian, Evelyn seems quite taken with that gentleman," she said with feigned innocence.

Inside, she was seething with envy.

Evelyn always attracted such exceptional men.

Vincent Ashcroft scoffed. "She relies on beauty and manipulation, nothing more."

He turned to Isabella.

"I heard you and Adrian have been together over a year. When's the wedding?"

He preferred Adrian marry someone of equal standing.

It would elevate the company further.

Surpassing Sterling Manor within a decade was within reach.

Then even Sebastian Cortez would have to step aside.

If only Christian were still here.

Vincent's hostility toward Evelyn stemmed from her alliance with Sebastian.

His sworn rival.

Isabella lowered her eyes demurely.

"That depends on Adrian's wishes."

Vincent thumped his chest.

"Leave the wedding plans to me. My family specializes in events."

Adrian cut him off coldly.

"Since when did you become so talkative?"

With that, he strode away.

Julian Roscente walked ahead, shoulders slumped.

He regretted how he had treated Evelyn.

His father had authenticated those antiques on his advice.

Every piece was a forgery.

They suspected sabotage.

But the mastermind remained hidden.

Adrian suddenly recalled Evelyn's warning.

"What were the results on those antiques?"

Julian's eyes turned icy.

"All fakes. We lost millions."

Adrian concealed his shock.

Evelyn had been right.

He needed to reassess his ex-wife.

Isabella's heart skipped a beat.

Evelyn truly had that ability.

Identifying counterfeits through a screen.

This woman was more dangerous than she'd imagined.

But Julian would never uncover the truth.

A shadow crossed her eyes.

Passing Evelyn's private room, Adrian hesitated.

Then continued walking.

Isabella was already plotting tonight's scheme.

She would make Julian believe Evelyn had deceived him.

That way Cassandra Valentine could secure the Roscente heir.

Controlling the Roscentes was easier than controlling Adrian.

She quickly messaged Cassandra with the plan.

The reply came instantly.

Agreed.
###Chapter 188

The crystal chandelier cast dazzling reflections across the luxurious private dining room.

Waiters brought in exquisite dishes one after another.

Everyone wore strained smiles.
###Chapter 189

This tainted broth would become irrefutable evidence against Evelyn.

Once Cassandra got what she wanted, she'd be even more indebted to Isabella.

Scarlett Orlando had deliberately stood them up.

###Chapter 191

Erratic heartbeat. Burning skin.

"How noble of you, Vincent." Her red lips curved. "Pity you aimed it in the wrong direction."

Cassandra lurked in the corner, nails digging into her palms.

Sebastian burst through the door, his suit jacket damp with night dew.

"Evelyn!" He rushed to her side in three quick strides.

Adrian's eyes narrowed at the sight of this persistent man.

"Perfect timing, Sebastian." Evelyn smiled sweetly. "Be my witness."

He tenderly tucked a loose strand of hair behind her ear. "Anything for you."

They walked out side by side, their silhouettes painfully harmonious.

Adrian's chest tightened. Suddenly, he remembered the name on her ID.

Evelyn Roland.

Even her name had been a lie.

The glass doors of the station slid shut, reflecting his stormy expression.
###Chapter 198

Adrian Valentine's lips curled into a self-deprecating smile. His heart felt like it was being torn apart.

So it had all been lies.

Vincent Ashcroft stood before him, pale as a ghost. "Adrian, save my family. I can't go bankrupt."

Adrian's gaze slid past him, landing on Cassandra Valentine in the distance. Rage surged through him.

"Vincent, Evelyn and I are divorced. What does she have to do with you? Why did you send people to hurt her?"

His voice was ice. "Do you know what it means to destroy a woman? How could you be so cruel?"

Vincent frowned. "I... I did it for you—"

"Don't say it was for me!" Adrian cut him off sharply. "I never asked for this. My affairs are none of your concern."

He took a step closer. "And are you even sure Evelyn was behind it?"

Vincent lowered his head. "No. Isabella said Evelyn drugged you to win you back, but Julian Roscente was the one who got poisoned. Then she latched onto Sebastian Cortez... I just wanted to teach her a lesson."

"A lesson?" Adrian laughed coldly. "You call that a lesson? She was once my woman!"

His voice turned deadly quiet. "We're done here. If you truly believe you did nothing wrong, go ask Julian. He'll give you your answers."

Right now, he had no time for anyone.

Adrian turned and walked away without looking back. So it was Isabella's doing. What a fool, being used without even realizing it.

Vincent stared at his retreating figure, his expression darkening. "Adrian, you're turning your back on me too?"

He shouted into the empty hallway, "Evelyn, you bitch! Because of you, brothers are turning against each other! Because of you, my family is ruined! Don't let me see you again!"

His chest ached even more after the outburst.

Then he thought of Cassandra.

She approached him gracefully. "Vincent, go home and handle your affairs first. We'll meet again once everything is settled."

Vincent gazed at her adoringly. He had loved her for so long. "Cassandra, you'll stand by me through this, won't you?"

Her eyes flickered. Why would she waste time on a fallen rich kid? She was meant for men like Julian Roscente, with real power and wealth. The Ashcrofts were just a failing wedding planning company.

Still, she smiled sweetly. "Vincent, I'll be here for you. Come to me if you need anything."

Vincent was enchanted by her gentle words. "Cassandra, you're all I have left."

She hid a smirk. Vincent was too impulsive—this downfall was his own fault. Men like him were only good as backups.

She seized the moment to stir the pot. "It's all Evelyn's fault. If not for her, the Ashcrofts wouldn't be in this mess."

Vincent's eyes darkened. It was because of Evelyn... and his own selfishness. "Let me take you home."

"No need." Cassandra declined softly. "Your family's situation is urgent. You should go."

Then she added slyly, "If all else fails, ask my brother to beg Evelyn to persuade Sebastian. As long as Sebastian doesn't pull his investment, the Ashcrofts can be saved."

She knew Adrian would never help Vincent. This way, Adrian would lose another true friend. And her own brother would benefit.

Everything Adrian had would eventually belong to her and her brother. He was just a tool for making money.

Vincent had always blamed his father's poor negotiation skills for their failed deal with Sebastian. That was why he resented him.

He never knew they had actually worked together.

Why hadn't his father told him?
###Chapter 199

"I'll walk you to the car," Vincent Ashcroft said softly.

Evelyn Roland nodded.

Vincent hailed a taxi and watched it drive away before turning back.

Inside the car, Evelyn's worried face reflected on her phone screen. The internet was flooded with vicious insults targeting Vincent.

She knew too well how ruthless the Ashcroft family's rivals could be. Tomorrow would only get worse.

~The Ashcroft heir is truly despicable. Ruining someone's reputation ruins their entire life.

~Rich heirs don't care about ordinary people. They step on others' suffering for fun.

~Serves him right for going bankrupt! Let's see who tramples whom when he's left with nothing!

Vincent unlocked his phone. The barrage of hateful comments stabbed at his eyes.

The last one made his fingers tremble.

Evelyn's words suddenly echoed in his ears. She said they always took pleasure in her pain.

He had simply disliked her aloof demeanor.

Only now did he understand the depth of his regret.

How could he have been so reckless?

Was it worth destroying the entire Ashcroft family over a moment of pride?

Evelyn was cunning. He had only meant to teach her a lesson.

But had he truly been wrong?

......

The moment Evelyn entered her apartment, she dialed Isabella Langley's number.

"Did you see the news, Isabella? The Ashcrofts are finished."

Isabella already knew but wondered why Evelyn was calling now.

"Aren't you supposed to be with Julian Roscente at the hotel?"

"It failed," Evelyn gritted her teeth. "Evelyn took him away."

"What?" Isabella's voice rose sharply. "Weren't you following them?"

To lose track like this—what an idiot.

"The elevator doors closed too fast..." Evelyn's voice wavered. "Now I'm afraid Vincent will realize we used him."

Isabella laughed lightly. "He acted on impulse. Who can he blame but himself?"

Too bad this fool didn't go all the way.

Evelyn caught her meaning. "I understand."

Vincent wouldn’t dare accuse her.

"Don’t worry," Isabella said, as if reading her thoughts. "He won’t."

"But I have an idea," Isabella added suddenly. "We can let someone else tell Vincent."

Evelyn's eyes lit up. "Tell me!"

After hearing Isabella's plan, Evelyn stood frozen, phone in hand.

If executed well, this could destroy Evelyn completely.

If not... Adrian Valentine would kill her.

Remembering the way Adrian looked at Evelyn, she bit her lower lip.

They were all just women he'd discarded anyway.

Evelyn walked to the study and retrieved a spare phone.

At the very least, she’d see what Vincent would choose.
###Chapter 200

Vincent Ashcroft stood before the villa's entrance when his phone screen suddenly lit up.

He glanced down, brows furrowing slightly.

This anonymous message was suspiciously timed.

Could the proposed solution in the text actually save the Ashcroft family?

His gaze lingered on the tightly shut door before he finally turned away.

Sacrificing some country girl meant nothing for the sake of his family.

Adrian Valentine had already discarded her anyway.

Vincent didn't realize this decision would condemn him to eternal ruin.

......

Sebastian Orlando escorted Evelyn Roland home, taking the opportunity to visit the children.

The moment he saw them, a flicker of pain crossed his eyes.

Thankfully, they resembled their mother more.

"Tristan, Felicia, this is Uncle Sebastian," Evelyn introduced gently.

Sebastian suddenly spoke up. "Call me Dad instead. Evelyn, let me be their father."

"What?" She froze.

His eyes crinkled with amusement. "As their godfather, I mean."

Evelyn nodded in agreement. The children did need paternal affection.

Yet something about his smile felt eerily familiar.

Sebastian bent down to scoop up Felicia.

"Come to Daddy, sweetheart."

Felicia immediately grabbed his ear.

"Little troublemaker. Don't you like Daddy?"

He gently squeezed her tiny hand, heart melting.

These were Evelyn's children.

Evelyn laughed while holding her son. "She's copying her brother. He always tugs on Great-grandfather's ears too."

Sebastian affectionately pinched Felicia's cheek. "Daddy loves his mischievous girl."

Felicia suddenly leaned in, planting a sloppy kiss on his face.

Evelyn chuckled. "Look how much your goddaughter adores you."

Shaking his head in mock exasperation, Sebastian said, "Let's go. I'll join you for dinner."

At the dining table, Victoria Laurent had prepared grilled meat and chicken porridge.

After the children were taken away, Sebastian asked softly, "Have your wounds healed completely?"

"Long ago." Evelyn kept her eyes on her porridge.

His gaze turned tender. "Don't take such risks again."

She'd been too reckless with herself these past years.

"I know. Now eat." Her voice was barely audible.

Sebastian placed a piece of grilled meat on her plate. "Come shopping with me tomorrow? We'll get things for the children."
###Chapter 201

Evelyn felt Sebastian's smile was strangely familiar, yet she couldn't place it.

She'd known him for years, but this reunion felt different somehow.

"Tristan and Felicia will love their godfather's gifts," Evelyn said with a smile.

Oddly, the hollow feeling in her chest vanished whenever he sat beside her.

This inexplicable sense of comfort puzzled her.

As night deepened, Sebastian walked with her through the neighborhood.

His stories from abroad kept her laughing.

It was nearly midnight when he finally rose to leave.

"I live right across the street. Call me anytime." His shadow stretched long under the streetlamp.

Evelyn's eyes widened. "When did you move here?"

"While you were recovering." His voice softened. "I didn't want to disturb you."

Warmth bloomed in her chest at having an old friend so close.

"Don't tell Scarlett about the children yet," she reminded him.

Sebastian's gaze flickered before he nodded.

He hesitated, then asked quietly, "Is it really over with Adrian?"

Evelyn's lashes fluttered as she looked away.

"That divorce was final long ago." She changed the subject. "It's late—you should rest."

The pain in Sebastian's chest sharpened at her evasiveness.

She clearly hadn't moved on.

"Goodnight," he murmured.

Too preoccupied with thoughts of the wrong man, Evelyn missed the tenderness in his voice.

Only when her silhouette disappeared into the building did Sebastian turn away.

Upstairs, Gabrielle had just finished bathing the twins.

"Ethan was so tired today he started sucking his toes," Gabrielle chuckled.

Evelyn blinked. "Sucking his toes?"

"It's a normal developmental phase," Gabrielle explained. "Felicia's obsessed with her feet now."

Amused, Evelyn watched her daughter.

After Gabrielle left, she took out her phone to document their milestones.

Felicia babbled while clutching Evelyn's hair, showing no signs of sleepiness.

"Time for bed, sweetheart." Evelyn stroked the tiny fingers. "Mommy will come home early tomorrow."

Beside them, Tristan had already drifted into peaceful slumber.
###Chapter 202

Felicia lay down obediently, her tiny hands resting neatly by her sides.

Then she suddenly sat up and planted a loud kiss on Evelyn's cheek before settling back with a satisfied grin.

Just as Evelyn reached for the lamp, the little girl kicked off her blanket.

Her tiny foot landed squarely on her brother's waist as she pretended to sleep, eyes tightly shut.

Evelyn sighed in exasperation. "Felicia Roland, if your brother could talk, he'd scold you for sure."

She tucked the blanket back around her daughter.

"One more kick and you're getting a spanking."

Felicia blinked her big eyes and suddenly reached for the hem of Evelyn's shirt.

"You little schemer," Evelyn chuckled, pinching her nose.

First the blanket kick. Then the foot on her brother.

All leading to her real goal.

"Mm..." The baby finally got what she wanted, nursing contentedly with half-lidded eyes.

Within ten minutes, she was sound asleep.

Evelyn kissed her forehead and was about to sleep when her phone vibrated.

"Adrian Valentine" flashed on the screen.

She answered with a frown. "Yes?"

"Madam—"

"It's Evelyn," she cut in coldly. "Adrian and I are divorced."

Victor's voice was urgent. "Ms. Roland, the CEO is badly injured. He's been in the bath for an hour refusing to come out—"

"Is he dead?" Evelyn scoffed. "If not, call an ambulance. If yes, contact the morgue."

Her finger hovered over the end call button.

"Take your problems to Isabella. Don't bother me." She paused. "Did he expect mercy after sending thugs to ruin me tonight?"

The call disconnected with finality.

At the Valentine estate, Adrian leaned back on the sofa, listening to the dial tone through the speaker.

Victor swallowed hard. "Sir, she's truly furious this time..."

Before, she'd drop everything to rush home if he was hurt.

Now she wouldn't even spare a word of concern.

Adrian's jaw tightened. "Does she... really not care at all anymore?"

Victor sighed. "You pushed her away yet still hope she'll come back..."

The world didn't work that way.
###Chapter 203

"Ha! Need you ask? From the very beginning, you drove her away in the cruelest way possible. Even the deepest love would wither under such treatment."

"You forced her to sign that dangerous contract. She took a bullet and dug it out with her own hands."

"The second time, you pushed her to leave, and she walked away to spare you. Now she's back, and you're tormenting her worse than ever. Tonight wasn't just a misunderstanding—you tried to destroy her!"

Victor Ashcroft stepped back abruptly, regret flashing across his face.

Damn his loose tongue.

He swallowed hard, meeting Adrian Valentine's icy gaze. "Sir...you told me to speak freely..."

"Get out."

Victor nearly sagged with relief.

The devil seemed remorseful.

At least he'd sleep well tonight.

His boss, however, wouldn't.

Victor turned to leave.

"Wait." Adrian's voice froze him mid-step. "Investigate tonight's incident. Check on Julian Roscente at the hospital."

Victor's legs nearly gave out.

Too soon to celebrate.

Sleep? He wouldn't even see his bed tonight.

He trudged away, shoulders slumped.

Adrian stormed upstairs.

The master bedroom remained untouched since Evelyn Roland's departure—the lavender embroidered duvet, her skincare products on the vanity.

For over a year, he'd avoided this room.

Now he pulled out his phone and dialed.

Evelyn jolted upright at the ringing.

Had something happened to Adrian?

Seeing his name, she exhaled.

If he could call, he was fine.

Her finger slipped, accidentally answering.

"Hello," she forced out.

"Wife..."

Evelyn blinked.

Wife?

Drunk or delirious?

"Adrian Valentine, who's your wife? Careful, that tongue might fall off."

Bastard.

Hearing her sharp tone, Adrian's lips twitched upward.

"I didn't orchestrate tonight. Believe it or not, I'm not that vile."

"Now you deny it? I endured your false vows, your pretend love, but I won't tolerate you ruining me!"

Her voice shook with fury.

"Waaah—" Little Sophia woke crying.

An infant's wail pierced the line.

Adrian froze.

"Wife—"

Evelyn hung up and powered off her phone.

He stared at the screen, that cry echoing in his ears.

Had he heard it during their last call too?

A staggering suspicion took shape.

He redialed.

The number you have reached—

"Evelyn!" He gritted his teeth.

Then remembered the unusually calm child in his arms outside the hospital.
###Chapter 204

Adrian Valentine's grip tightened around his phone.

He immediately dialed Victor Ashcroft's number.

"Sir, I just arrived at the hotel to check the surveillance footage," Victor's voice was cautious.

"Get to the point." Adrian's tone was icy.

Victor swallowed hard on the other end. "Sir, Ms. Roland used a fake identity. I've checked every person named Evelyn in Vienna—none of them match her. The vehicles picking her up change daily, and the driver is suspiciously elusive. There's no record of her employment in our system either."

Victor exhaled in relief. "Thank goodness, sir. I've been working nonstop lately—I'm better suited for collecting paychecks than actual work."

"Enough." Adrian ended the call abruptly.

Evelyn Roland woke naturally to sunlight filtering through the sheer curtains.

Her two children still slept soundly beside her.

She dressed them carefully, moving quietly. Gabrielle Flores entered just as she finished.

"Sebastian's here," Gabrielle whispered with a wink. "He wants to take you to breakfast and shopping. And he looks extra dashing today."

Evelyn smiled. "Alright."

Gabrielle beamed. "I'll handle the kids. Christian's acupuncture is done—no need for you to visit today."

Evelyn's expression sobered. "Gabrielle, Christian's situation stays confidential. There's more to his attack years ago. I'll investigate properly once things settle."

"Don't worry." Gabrielle lifted the hungry Ethan, who was chewing his fingers. "Let's get breakfast first."

Downstairs, Sebastian Orlando had been waiting.

He took Ethan from Gabrielle, cradling the boy like precious porcelain.

"Sleep well last night?" he asked softly.

Evelyn adjusted Felicia in her arms. "They were angels—slept through mostly."

Sebastian's eyes flickered with concern. "I just hate seeing you exhausted."

"Sis! Check the news!" Victoria Laurent burst in, phone raised, her face pale.
###Chapter 205

Sebastian Orlando frowned slightly, his gaze fixed on Victoria Laurent.

Victoria's fingers trembled under his icy stare.

She had never seen such sharpness in his eyes before.

Immediately, she understood—now wasn't the right time for Evelyn to know the truth.

"Evelyn, have breakfast first." Victoria shoved her phone into her pocket, forcing a stiff smile. "We can check later. No need to ruin your appetite."

Evelyn sensed something was off.

But Victoria was right—it was too early to spoil the morning.

"Sebastian, eat up." She placed a fried dumpling in his bowl.

Sebastian smiled warmly. "After this, I'll take you shopping."

The table was spread with steaming porridge, golden-brown dumplings, and soft-boiled eggs—Evelyn's signature breakfast dishes.

Suddenly, she remembered how Adrian Valentine had loved her cooking.

Her fingers clenched.

Why was she thinking about that traitor again?

"Evelyn?" Sebastian noticed her pale expression. "Are you feeling unwell?"

She shook her head. "I'm fine."

Taking a bite of the dumpling, she savored the burst of juices.

Sebastian picked out the egg yolk and gently placed it in her bowl.

"You don't like yolks either?" Evelyn was surprised.

Just like Alexander Durand.

A flicker of nostalgia passed through Sebastian's eyes. "Alexander and I never liked them, even as kids."

Evelyn froze. She hadn't known that.

After breakfast, the children were left in Gabrielle Flores and Victoria's care.

Sebastian drove Evelyn to the mall for children's clothes.

Though Gabrielle and Victoria often bought outfits, Evelyn always chose the styles herself.

She knew Adrian's tactics too well.

If he discovered the children existed, he'd stop at nothing to take them.

Every trace had to be erased.

Even if he'd heard the baby's cries last night, he'd find no leads.

Sebastian's SUV pulled into the mall's underground garage.

As he leaned over to fasten her seatbelt, Evelyn caught his crisp pine scent—strangely familiar.

"You can check your phone now." Sebastian started the engine. "But promise me you won't overreact. Let me handle this."

Evelyn unlocked her screen.

A headline exploded across it:

Nathan Aldridge's Secretary Caught Seducing Vincent Ashcroft—Revenge Ensues

Accompanied by photos of her with Vincent, and his public apology.
###Chapter 206

Evelyn stared at her phone screen, fingertips trembling slightly.

The flood of vicious comments cut into her heart like knives.

"That slut is back to seduce men again!"

"First Adrian Valentine, now Vincent Ashcroft. How shameless can she be?"

"Pretty face means nothing when you're rotten to the core!"

Evelyn took a deep breath and locked her phone.

She walked to the window, gazing at the distant skyscrapers.

Vincent had crossed the line this time.

Not only had he falsely accused her of drugging someone, but he'd also manipulated public opinion against her.

Evelyn picked up her phone and dialed Vincent's number.

The call rang for a long time before being answered.

"Evelyn?" Vincent's voice dripped with mockery. "Finally crawling back to beg?"

"Cleverer than you," he sneered. "The whole world knows what kind of trash you are now."

Dead silence on the other end.

"Impossible!" he shouted. "Stop spreading nonsense!"

Evelyn chuckled. "Call your father right now if you don't believe me."

"Idiot." Her tone turned glacial. "Why was it specifically the soup Isabella Langley brought?"

Another stretch of silence.

"Vincent," Evelyn said finally, "tune into the financial news at 3 PM."

She hung up without waiting for a response.

Evelyn turned to her computer.

She opened her email and began sending out meticulously prepared documents.

Meanwhile, Adrian stood before his office windows.

He scowled at the news on his phone.

"That moron Vincent..." he muttered darkly.

Adrian took the tablet. The video clearly showed Isabella slipping something into the soup.

"Just as I thought." His eyes turned icy.

Elsewhere, Julian was signing his discharge papers.

"Mr. Roscente, the doctors recommend—" his assistant began anxiously.

"Shut up." Julian's face darkened. "Take me to Vincent's place."

At that same moment, Isabella clinked glasses with Cassandra Valentine in celebration.

"Let's see that bitch recover from this!" Isabella crowed.

Cassandra sipped her wine. "Vincent made such a useful fool."

###Chapter 207

A cold glint flashed in Sebastian Orlando's eyes as his fingers tapped twice on the steering wheel.

"Evelyn, drink some water." He unscrewed the thermos and handed it to her.

Evelyn Roland cradled the cup lid, taking small sips as the warm liquid soothed her throat.

"You're so thoughtful, Sebastian."

"Dad! What's going on? Didn't the company just recover?"

"I was just trying to save the company—"

###Chapter 208

Vincent Ashcroft Sr. stood by the floor-to-ceiling window, a cigarette between his fingers.

Smoke curled around him as his gaze pierced through the glass, settling on the distant skyscrapers.

"The tax issue was just the trigger." His voice was hoarse. "The company's cash flow dried up months ago. Those taxes have been overdue for three months."

###Chapter 209

Vincent Ashcroft Sr. let out a heavy sigh, his gaze complex as he stared at his son. "You're right. The Yangs can't touch us. But I've checked—Sebastian Cortez hasn't made a move against us either. Yet if he terminates our partnership, we're finished."

So close to success, only to fail at the last moment.

"That Sterling Manor heiress is formidable. She developed it in just four years. If not for their production limitations, they'd never have partnered with us." A bitter smile twisted his lips. "My technology isn't inferior to hers. After finally gaining recognition..."

Disappointment etched his features as he regarded his son. "Twenty-six years old, yet still acting like a reckless boy who doesn't know his place."

Selfish. Arrogant. Wealth had blinded him to reality.

And this was only the beginning.

Vincent Sr. turned to find his wife. With the political winds shifting in Vienna, self-preservation was paramount.

For over a year, he'd sensed something amiss. The Roscentes had been the first target.

Before leaving, he cautioned Julian: "Tell your father to tread carefully in the coming days."

"Stay with him. Make him see reason." Vincent Sr. checked his watch. "I leave in an hour."

His shoulders slumped as he ascended the stairs. Some realizations, only his son could reach alone.

Vincent collapsed onto the sofa, his gaze hollow. "Julian... I never imagined the Ashcrofts would fall this far."

Never in his wildest dreams had he thought he'd plummet from the heights of privilege.

Julian's voice turned grave. "Believe it or not, we were both set up last night. Cassandra Valentine drugged me."
###Chapter 210

Vincent Ashcroft shot to his feet, his eyes bloodshot as he glared at Julian Roscente. His fists clenched with audible cracks. "Julian Roscente, how dare you? Cassandra would never drug you!"

His chest heaved violently, refusing to believe Cassandra Valentine could scheme against Julian.

After all these years of unspoken feelings, she couldn’t possibly be oblivious.

Evelyn’s words from last night suddenly echoed in his mind. A chill ran down his spine. Could it be...?

No. Cassandra would never fall for this playboy. The number of women he’d toyed with was countless.

Seeing Vincent’s emotional outburst, Julian said nothing more and turned to leave the Ashcroft residence.

At the Langley villa, Isabella Langley sipped black tea from a bone china cup, her movements deliberate.

Isabella wanted nothing more than to eliminate Evelyn, but the opportunity never seemed to present itself.

"Every plan we've tried has failed, Giselle. This time, we used Vincent Ashcroft against her, and instead, it backfired—his family went bankrupt."

"That idiot Vincent," Isabella scoffed, her lips curling in contempt.

Isabella glanced around warily. "Not here. I just saw Adrian heading this way. Let's go find him."

The moment they disappeared around the corner, Vincent Ashcroft emerged from the shadows.

His gaze burned with hatred as he stared at Isabella's retreating back.

So it was all the Langleys' scheme.

Vincent turned toward the private lounge where Adrian was waiting and knocked.

The door opened, and Adrian frowned at the sight of him.

"Disappointed to see me?" Vincent smirked coldly.

Adrian studied the man before him. In just a few days, Vincent had changed—his usual recklessness now tempered with a dangerous calm.

"Or were you expecting your fiancée instead?" Vincent strode past him and dropped onto the sofa.

"You heard everything?" Adrian's voice was low.

He stood abruptly, suddenly remembering Evelyn—her cold elegance, her unyielding pride.

"Vincent!" Adrian's voice turned icy.

"In six months, I'll make sure you both pay in blood." Vincent's smile was mocking. "A scumbag and a bitch—what a perfect match. Consider this an early wedding gift, since—"

"—women as 'virtuous' as Isabella are hard to come by."

Without another glance, he walked out.

Adrian remained still, his expression unreadable.

Was this what he had wanted?

To watch everyone he cared about drift further and further away.
###Chapter 239

Evelyn strode through the banquet hall in her stilettos, scanning every corner. Where had that glutton Nathan disappeared to now? She sighed inwardly.

"Time to go home." Thoughts of her waiting children made her turn toward the lounge.

Vincent's body tensed.

"Too bad," Lucien taunted. "She warmed my bed last night. Think a penniless wretch like you could ever impress her?"

"Does it hurt?" Her whisper was deceptively soft.

Vincent's pupils dilated violently.
###Chapter 240

He felt all strength drain from his body.

Underground parking garage.

His entire body trembled, veins bulging on his hands.

Impressive intensity.

###Chapter 241

Evelyn paused mid-step. The once-arrogant young master of the Ashcroft family was now uncharacteristically deferential.

###Chapter 243

That announcement alone would trigger a bidding war among investors.

Those were his treasured reserves.

Her medical prowess was unparalleled.

###Chapter 244

"It's just a scratch. Don't overreact."

He reluctantly handed Sophia back to Gabrielle, worried about passing anything to the child.

Evelyn approached with the medical kit.

"Thank you for this." Sebastian's voice was hoarse.

Victoria and Gabrielle tactfully took the children away.

"Take this first. One daily. Your condition will improve in six months."

Surprise flickered in Sebastian's eyes.

"Your medical skills remain impeccable."

Evelyn smiled faintly. "Years of practice."

She urged him to rest and personally walked him out.

Moonlight bathed the garden of swaying roses.

She remembered his promise—to fill a garden with roses for her.

Sebastian suddenly stopped.

"Evelyn, have you truly let go of Adrian?"
###Chapter 293

Evelyn gazed into Sebastian Orlando's deep eyes, sensing an uncanny familiarity about him tonight.

The way he scolded Isabella Langley with that roguish attitude was identical to Alexander Durand's mannerisms.

Meeting his expectant gaze, she dismissed her doubts. A person's essence couldn't change so easily. Alexander's unique aura wasn't something anyone could replicate.

"Sebastian, that chapter of my life is over. You should rest. I need to check on the children."

She turned to leave.

Sebastian watched her retreating figure, a shadow flickering in his eyes. Evelyn, have you really given up on me?

Only after confirming she'd safely entered the opposite apartment did he shut the door. The thought of Vincent Langley's successful scheme twisted his lips into an uncharacteristically cold smirk.

Vincent Langley, I'll make sure you savor every bitter drop of defeat.

The mineral atlas was exhausted. Even with Vincent's resources, not a single diamond remained to be mined.

Seeing Vincent's caller ID, her eyes turned glacial. So he's finally made contact.

Vincent's tone held an unfamiliar gentleness she'd never heard before.

"You're the only one who's seen that painting. Can you help me locate it?"

Evelyn smirked inwardly. The atlas had been destroyed long ago. This was her chance to toy with him. Those diamonds had fallen into her hands effortlessly.

"Mr. Langley, I've been searching for that painting too, but found no leads. I truly wish to fulfill Alexander's dream."

Everything proceeded according to plan. Next, she'd lure Vincent into his own trap.

"Chairman Langley, I'll keep searching and notify you immediately if anything surfaces."

Ending the call, her eyes hardened further.

Adrian Valentine's venomous threat to imprison her still haunted her. Knowing him, this vendetta ran deeper than just Alexander.

But with no concrete clues, her priority remained the children.

Vincent paced his bedroom like a caged predator.

Alexander had discovered ore a hundred times more valuable than diamonds. Without that painting, even the most advanced equipment couldn't pinpoint its location.

Alexander was a born genius. Finding that masterpiece meant acquiring wealth beyond imagination.
###Chapter 294

To amass a fortune that could rival nations—that was Vincent Langley's relentless pursuit.

Anyone who stood in his way would vanish without a trace.

The call connected, and Dominic Lombardi's voice came through.

"Mr. Langley."

"Have you uncovered Phoenix Group's background?"

Dominic's voice tensed. "Sir, they're too well-hidden. Not even a shadow of them can be traced. These people are highly trained—far beyond my clearance level."

Vincent narrowed his eyes.

Abroad, he could operate with impunity.

But on home soil, he had to tread carefully.

His path to legitimacy couldn't afford a single misstep.

A weighted silence filled the line.

Dominic knew how obsessively his boss coveted those diamonds.

They were the golden ticket into the world's elite.

"Sir, I've been monitoring the diamond situation. But the operation against Julian Roscente failed. He survived and is now hospitalized with Adrian Valentine."

Vincent's brow twitched.

Adrian was in the hospital too?

"Perfect," he sneered. "Now we have grounds to postpone his engagement to Isabella."

Dominic understood immediately.

Adrian's sudden interest in Isabella was clearly an investigation into the past.

After hanging up, Vincent stood before the floor-to-ceiling windows.

Years of meticulous planning, yet progress remained agonizingly slow.

What was Adrian compared to him?

If only he could secure Sebastian Cortez's alliance...

But that man cared only for power.

Downstairs in the living room, Isabella flipped through a script, noticing her mother's distracted expression.

"Mother, is something troubling you?" She closed the binder.

Eleanor Langley snapped out of her thoughts, forcing a smile. "Just missing your brother. Another year without him home for the holidays. The house feels incomplete."

Isabella handed her a teacup. "He's doing well abroad. Don't worry."

Eleanor stared blankly at the cup.

This wasn't her real daughter.

Where was her true child?

"Miss me already?" His tone was teasing.

Isabella's voice turned icy. "Cut the act. Track my mother's recent movements."

###Chapter 295

Adrian Valentine could never give her this kind of thrill.

On the day of the engagement.

She shouldn't care.

Julian Roscente woke at dawn on the third day.

No reaction.

Darkness.

Endless, suffocating darkness.

His fingers brushed cold metal bed rails.

###Chapter 296

[How Christian Lefèvre died is how your son got hurt.]

###Chapter 297

###Chapter 299

"Boss, Eleanor Langley has been quiet, but Isabella is investigating her mother's recent strange behavior."

A faint smile curved Evelyn's lips. "Let her dig. The best outcome would be uncovering the truth and watching them tear each other apart."

With Vincent Langley already frantic over the stolen diamonds, some family drama would make things even more entertaining.

###Chapter 300

Vincent Ashcroft Sr. sat by the window in the teahouse, sunlight streaming through the glass and casting a warm glow on his navy-blue jacket. He sipped his tea slowly, fingers tapping the table in rhythm with the opera playing in the background.

Julian’s fists clenched until his knuckles turned white. Had he misjudged Evelyn all along?

###Chapter 301

Vincent Ashcroft Sr. felt cold sweat trickling down his spine.

###Chapter 306

They appeared to be close confidantes, but each harbored their own hidden agendas.

"Vincent... Langley!" She spat out each syllable, her nails digging into her palms.

She'd always known her husband was a womanizer, but this—with her own daughter's mother-in-law—was beyond contempt.

A violent coughing fit seized her. She clutched her chest, but the searing pain refused to subside.

She'd severed ties with her own family to marry Vincent Langley all those years ago. It hadn't been love so much as admiration for his boldness.

His handsome face had captivated her briefly, but the novelty wore off within years. For him, she'd even risked criminal dealings.

Whatever affection remained between them had long since eroded—which was why she'd taken up with her assistant.

But this betrayal crossed every line.

The sender's ulterior motives were obvious, but betrayal was betrayal. Worse still was the realization that the daughter she'd raised wasn't hers.

"Madam, still not coming in today?"

"Jonathan," she rasped, "have someone track Vincent's movements. I want to know where he is right now."
###Chapter 307

Eleanor Langley leaned against the leather sofa, her face as pale as paper, fingers digging into the armrest.

Her eyes were red-rimmed, but she stubbornly refused to let the tears fall.

The concerned call warmed her heart slightly.

Since childhood, her life had been like a meticulously designed cage.

She had barely escaped the shackles of her family, only to sink into an even deeper quagmire.

Her husband's betrayal, the truth about her adopted daughter—each revelation stabbed like a dagger to the heart.

Love had never been the entirety of her life.

The Nine-City Alliance was a tangled web of power, full of unpredictable variables.

Margaret Valentine's methods were indeed formidable.
###Chapter 308

In today's volatile market, one misstep meant total ruin.

Sterling Manor had deep roots—this partnership meant nothing.

Market analysis predicted an industry freeze within six months.

The Lee family's breach was Margaret's doing.

Let the market teach them a brutal lesson.

Industry upheavals always hid opportunities within crises.

If Margaret dared meddle, she'd lose more than just a fingernail.

###Chapter 309

~Disgusting! Counting blood money before Alexander's body was cold!
~This woman belongs in hell!

Harrison's 300 million had been an elaborately baited trap all along.

Outside, the last rays of sunlight vanished behind gathering storm clouds.

Now she understood why Adrian Valentine's dangerous allure had captivated her friend.

If these two had conspired to keep secrets, Adrian would face her wrath when the truth came out.

She shook her head. "Not worth mentioning."

Sebastian's gaze softened as it lingered on Evelyn.

Diamonds always suited her radiance.

As long as she was unharmed.

He knew her well. Trivial attacks couldn't scratch her armor.

The official report called the Durand mansion fire an accident. But they both knew it was a massacre.

Always treating her like a child needing protection.

"Planning to torture me?" Her gaze turned arctic.

She knew exactly what that blinding interrogation light could do—it would ruin her eyesight.

Vincent Langley's influence had clearly reached the police.

Nanyang sneered. "Make this easy on yourself."

"And if I'm innocent? You think a flimsy bottle is enough to convict me?" Evelyn didn't back down an inch.

"No one walks out of here once we've got them." Nanyang slammed his palm on the table. "Talk! Did you kill him or not?"
###Chapter 347

Evelyn's lips curled slightly, a hint of mockery flashing in her eyes.

In this world, few truly stood for justice.

Vincent's methods were indeed masterful.

Escaping unscathed wouldn't be easy for her.

Vincent secretly controlled several underground factions, amassing wealth effortlessly.

He never showed his face—plenty were eager to do his dirty work.

Everything he did now was just an attempt to whitewash his reputation, to become "respectable."

Too bad he was already knee-deep in the muck.

This was the first time he'd encountered such an opponent.

Calm under interrogation.

And able to see right through him.

Evelyn replied lightly, "You know exactly what I mean."

Nanyang's eyes darkened, murderous intent flickering.

"Evelyn, this vial contains a lethal poison. Julian Roscente won't survive."

To Evelyn, he was nothing but a greedy, pathetic clown.

Nanyang still refused to give up, baiting her to confess.

Evelyn saw the greed he could barely conceal.

Evelyn smiled. "Dying before fulfilling your ambitions."

She knew all too well—in this world, a person's worth depended on their position.

Vincent was indeed at the height of his power now.

Her words struck a nerve.

"Lights." Nanyang changed tactics.

Harsh beams blasted into Evelyn's eyes.

Tears welled up uncontrollably.

Nanyang sneered. "Evelyn—"

###Chapter 348

"Nanyang! Who authorized you to use coercive tactics?" Captain Song shoved open the interrogation room door and switched off the blinding spotlight.

The mastermind remained at large.

Where had he gone wrong?

Adrian's jaw tightened. So Julian had been playing the long game.

###Chapter 349

~Money can buy anything these days?

She'd only taken money to do this job—she never expected to be exposed.

Captain Song remained unmoved.

Her legs gave out, collapsing beneath her.

The live chat exploded.

~She's definitely guilty!
~Look how she's trembling with fear.
~Someone's targeting Evelyn.

The mastermind still hadn't shown themselves, but she wasn't in a hurry.

The police department's official website soon released a statement.

The real culprit was a man who had confessed to the crime.

Evidence of the reporter taking bribes to smear Evelyn was also made public.

Public opinion flipped instantly.

Furious, she smashed everything within reach.

He'd arranged everything perfectly.

###Chapter 350

This meticulously planned scheme had been orchestrated by Vincent and his daughter together.

The little girl in the picture was innocent and carefree, her features unmistakably Vincent's. She had never doubted the girl's parentage.

Only by stirring the hornet's nest could she force Vincent to reveal the truth of that year.

This family would soon crumble.

She had married Vincent in a fit of pride, only to realize now how foolish she had been.

Even with his vast wealth, such waste was unbearable.

The viciousness in her gaze sent a chill down Vincent's spine.

Of his three daughters, Isabella and his other illegitimate child were his favorites.

Outwardly sweet and docile, but at their core, just as merciless as he was.

In his line of work, trust was paramount.

Knowing when to cut losses was survival.

Using a scapegoat was too risky.

Win, and they'd have everything. Lose, and it would be their ruin.

If the Roscentes couldn't be taken down, they'd find another target.

One by one, they'd climb to the top.

A country bumpkin—how did she have so many powerful allies?

She would destroy it. But her last attempt had failed.

The more Isabella thought about it, the more her hatred festered.

She had pulled so many strings for this scheme.

On their divorce day, he'd smudged her lipstick on purpose—a show for Evelyn.

In truth, nothing had ever happened between them.

Several attempts to eliminate Victoria Laurent had failed, costing him valuable operatives.

The patriarch massaged his temples.

Harrison Jr. slammed his palms on the table.

"While Evelyn hosted tea exhibitions and gifted million-dollar Da Hong Pao to secure partnerships?"

"Now Montreal's herbs are everywhere, and our stockpile is worthless!"

"Our shares will hit limit-down today—all thanks to you!"

His glare turned icy.

"Grandmother knew your first love's family had petty minds. Now your life's work is destroyed by this daughter-in-law."

The door crashed shut behind him.

Eleanor and the elder Macmillan exchanged stunned looks.

"Father... what bankruptcy is he talking about?"
###Chapter 387

The teacup slipped from Elder Li's grasp and shattered on the floor.

News of the Montreal Herbal Market's massive supply release tightened his chest.

His steward stumbled into the study, breathless. "Master, disaster strikes!"

Elder Li's brow furrowed.

The Li Corporation had weathered centuries of storms. What could mere price fluctuations do to them?

"Compose yourself!" he snapped.

The steward paled. "This is different! Our stock prices have plummeted. Montreal's herbs match our quality but cost only a third of ours!"

Elder Li shot to his feet.

"Our stockpiled herbs are now worthless!" The steward's voice trembled. "Suppliers are canceling orders and flocking to Montreal instead!"

Elder Li staggered backward.

Madam Li steadied him, lips quivering. "How did this happen?"

The steward wiped his brow. "Sterling Manor extended an olive branch first. After we refused, they turned to Montreal. Their bulk purchases created a surplus..."

"The perishable herbs have hit rock-bottom prices!"

Elder Li's legs gave out as he collapsed into his armchair.

Their warehouses overflowed with now-worthless inventory.

Plummeting stocks. Canceled contracts.

A century-old empire teetered on the brink.

"Father!" Madam Li stamped her foot in distress.

Elder Li recalled Nathan Aldridge's generous offer yesterday. Bitter regret twisted his gut.

Worse still, last night's public spectacle had broadcast their rift with Sterling Manor to the world.

"Master!" The steward gasped. "Notoginseng prices crashed from hundreds to mere dozens!"

Elder Li's face turned ashen.

Their stockpiled notoginseng had cost triple the current market rate.

"Ruined..." he whispered.

A legacy built over generations crumbled in a day.

The steward cried out again. "Sterling Manor purchased thirty thousand pounds in three hours! All shipped to Nine-City Alliance Pharmaceuticals!"

Darkness swallowed Elder Li's vision.
###Chapter 388

Old Mr. Macmillan lay on the hospital bed, his face as pale as parchment.

The butler's words echoed relentlessly in his mind.

Had they chosen to partner with Sterling Manor, the Macmillan family could have earned billions.

Now they'd not only missed the opportunity but were also mired in scandal.

Mrs. Macmillan knelt by the bedside, sobbing hysterically.

She knew full well—if the patriarch fell, her position in the family would crumble.

Last night's grand banquet had become the laughingstock of the entire business world.

Media outlets were plastered with reports of the Macmillan disgrace.

"That wretched Evelyn Roland!" Mrs. Macmillan spat through gritted teeth.

The butler calmly dialed emergency services.

The wail of sirens pierced the sky.

In Vincent Langley's office, red alerts flashed across the computer screen.

"Continue the acquisitions. Buy up everything available," he ordered into the phone.

His assistant hesitated. "Sir, what about Macmillan's Northern Division—"

"Leave that. Secure the core assets first."

At the same moment, Adrian Valentine studied stock market charts.

Nathan Aldridge's call came through.

"President Valentine, someone's competing for Northern Division shares."

Adrian's gaze turned icy. "Identify them."

"It's Horizon Tech."

Adrian's long fingers tapped the desk.

He'd always suspected Vincent Langley was more than he seemed.

"Expedite the process. We must secure Northern Division."

The call ended just as his office door burst open.

Mrs. Macmillan stormed in, fury radiating from her.

Victor Ashcroft followed helplessly. "Sir, I couldn't stop her—"

Adrian lifted his eyes, their chill palpable.

Mrs. Macmillan slammed her palms on the desk.

"Adrian Valentine! You must save the Macmillan family!"

Her shrill voice filled the room.

"If not for helping your mother, we wouldn't be in this mess!"

Adrian leaned back leisurely in his chair.

"Mind your tone, Mrs. Macmillan."
###Chapter 389

Adrian Valentine watched Mrs. Langley with icy disdain, recalling how she had humiliated Evelyn. His gaze darkened.

He rose slowly, a mocking smile playing on his lips.

"Mrs. Langley, I'm considering acquiring the Langley Group. The offer will be... fair."

Her face paled, fingers trembling around her phone.

"Have you lost your mind?"

She couldn't believe his audacity.

The call to Margaret Valentine went unanswered—her lifeline now useless.

Mrs. Langley's knuckles whitened.

The woman who had once schemed beside her now avoided her like the plague.

"After decades of friendship with your mother, this is how you repay me?"

Adrian scoffed, his eyes sharp as blades.

"Do you truly not understand the Langley Group's current position?"

He stepped closer, voice glacial.

"In three days, you'll learn what it means to be abandoned by all."

Mrs. Langley staggered back, finally grasping the gravity of her situation.

She still didn't realize—she was merely Margaret's pawn.

Adrian's motive was simple: justice for his wife.

At the Valentine mansion, Margaret trembled as she opened an envelope.

The contents made her legs give way, collapsing onto the sofa.

"How...?"

The paternity test struck her like a bomb.

Simultaneously, Eleanor Langley received identical documents.

Her nails dug into her palms as she stared at the results.

"Vincent Langley, you monster!"

Tears blurred her vision. Now she understood why Isabella was favored.

It had all been a lie.

In Regal Heights, Evelyn silently watched the surveillance feed.

Victoria Laurent frowned in confusion.

"Evelyn, these connections are... convoluted."

Evelyn shook her head, gaze profound.

"The daughter Eleanor seeks might be closer than we think."
###Chapter 390

Evelyn tapped her fingers lightly on the desk, brows slightly furrowed. "Could it be they don't know about their relationship?"

Victoria immediately shook her head. "Impossible. Eleanor clearly knows Isabella is her daughter. Otherwise, why would she defend Isabella at every turn against you?"

Evelyn's pupils constricted sharply, her voice tense. "Are you saying Eleanor knowingly let siblings be together?"

The question had haunted her all night.

Victoria sighed. "Unless your suspicion is correct—they're both unaware."

Evelyn fell into deep thought.

She had already delivered the two paternity test results to Eleanor and Margaret today. Now she waited for their reactions.

"No news from Margaret yet?"

Victoria glanced at her phone. "Zachary's keeping watch. Nothing so far."

Something felt off to Evelyn. Had Vincent and Margaret been entangled in their youth?

The thought of Adrian's father's mysterious death stirred more questions in her mind.

But the past was like smoke—impossible to grasp.

"Notify me immediately if there's any update." Evelyn stood. "Scarlett invited me shopping."

Victoria gave her a concerned look. "Don't waste tears on that scoundrel. Let them destroy each other."

A flicker passed through Evelyn's eyes. "I stopped caring long ago."

Before leaving, she visited the nursery to feed her twins.

Outside Scarlett's studio building, Evelyn dialed her friend. "I'm here. Come down."

A groan came through the phone. "Grace, my period just started. Bring me some pads, please?"

Evelyn exhaled in exasperation.

She turned into the nearby convenience store, heading straight for the feminine products aisle.

As she scanned her items at checkout, a familiar icy presence approached.

Her fingers stilled. From the corner of her eye, she saw Adrian buying bottled water at the next register.

She averted her gaze instantly, paid, and hurried out.

Adrian watched her retreating figure, frustration tightening his jaw. He loosened his tie irritably.

Now she couldn't even bear to look at him?

Evelyn quickened her pace toward the elevators. Only when certain Adrian hadn't followed did she relax slightly.

Memories of him with Isabella churned her stomach.

The elevator doors began closing—until a slender, masculine hand shot between them.

The doors slid open once more.
###Chapter 391

The elevator doors slid shut.

Evelyn's gaze locked onto those familiar slender fingers. Her pupils contracted sharply.

When the doors reopened, Adrian's imposing figure filled the doorway. His tailored suit and immaculate tie radiated an aura of icy detachment.

She instinctively shifted toward the corner.

Her nails dug into her palms as she stared at the floor.

"Running away?" Adrian's deep voice echoed in the confined space. "You weren't so timid before."

Evelyn's head snapped up, disgust flashing in her eyes. "You misunderstand, Mr. Valentine. I simply find your presence nauseating."

"Nauseating?" His laugh was cold. "You didn't seem sickened when you were flirting with other men behind my back."

Her chest rose and fell rapidly. She'd explained this countless times—now it just felt absurd.

The air grew thick with tension.

Adrian's eyes dropped to her shopping bag. A mocking smirk appeared. "Even changed your sanitary pad brand?"

Her knuckles whitened around the bag. "We've been divorced for two years, Adrian."

"And?"

"And I want you to stay away." Each word was deliberate. "The sight of you makes me physically ill."

His gaze turned glacial. "Then why don't you leave Vienna?"

The words stabbed like a blade. Evelyn drew a steadying breath. "You're the one who should disappear. I'm staying—to marry, have children, and live well."

"Marry?" He stepped closer abruptly. "Who would dare take you?"

The doors pinged open.

"Evelyn!" Sebastian stood outside with a warm smile. "I'm here for our shopping trip."

The ice in her expression melted instantly. "Sebastian."

His eyes flickered to Adrian, brows furrowing. He naturally took the bag from her hands. "Scarlett's waiting in the car."

Adrian watched their retreating figures, his expression darkening.
###Chapter 392

Adrian Valentine met his challenging gaze with a cold smirk.

Was Sebastian Orlando the man Evelyn Roland wanted to marry?

He'd investigated this man thoroughly.

Not an ordinary opponent.

His looks rivaled Adrian's own.

The power behind him was unfathomable.

"Fine. I could use someone to carry my bags." Evelyn walked out without glancing back.

Adrian pressed the elevator button, his gaze sharp as a blade on her retreating figure.

Sebastian smoothly placed a hand near Evelyn's waist.

Adrian's pupils constricted, forced to watch the elevator doors close between them.

Once out of Adrian's sight, Sebastian immediately withdrew his hand.

"Was he bothering you again?" His voice was low.

Evelyn shook her head. "Just ran into him at the supermarket."

Sebastian knew better but chose not to press.

A man like Adrian didn't deserve to stand beside her.

They'd just entered Scarlett Orlando's studio when Evelyn discreetly passed her a sanitary pad.

Scarlett emerged from the bathroom clutching her stomach. "Sebastian, take Evelyn shopping. I'm not feeling well."

Sebastian stiffened.

Couldn't this girl watch her words?

Evelyn's ears turned pink.

Scarlett successfully pushed them out the door.

The elevator opened to reveal Adrian rushing toward them.

Victor Ashcroft looked frantic. "Sir, Isabella Langley's been kidnapped!"

Adrian's brow furrowed. "Mobilize everyone. Find her immediately!"

His gaze brushed past Evelyn without recognition as he strode by.

A sharp pain pierced Evelyn's heart.

After two years, he could still panic for that woman.

Victor deliberately raised his voice. "Madam, the kidnappers have contacted Mr. Langley."

Evelyn's eyes gleamed.

Both Mrs. Langley and Mrs. Valentine knew the truth now.

This dog-eat-dog drama would be entertaining to watch.
###Chapter 393

Sebastian Orlando noticed Evelyn Roland's distracted gaze, his lips curving into a mysterious smile. "Evelyn, what's on your mind?"

She blinked back to reality, her eyes crinkling with warmth. "Sebastian, I was just thinking about what to buy while shopping later."

Truthfully, she lacked nothing. Sterling Manor had exclusive designers crafting custom outfits for her, with each season's collection handled by top-tier fashion houses.

Occasionally, she designed a few pieces herself—each one a unique masterpiece.

"I know you have everything." Sebastian's gaze softened with affection. "Now that the herb issue is resolved, what's next?"

This brilliant girl mastered everything with astonishing speed. But only he knew the relentless effort behind her achievements.

He felt unworthy in comparison.

"Come on, I'll take you somewhere." He took her hand, leading her toward the parking lot.

Evelyn scrolled through her phone. The news of Isabella Langley's kidnapping had already topped the trending list.

Comments flooded in:
～Our goddess must be safe! Mr. Valentine, go save her!
～Who dares lay a finger on our Isabella? What are the police doing?
～Oh my god! She just got nominated for Best Actress! "Phoenix Feather" made her a star overnight!

Fans eagerly anticipated a heroic rescue.

Evelyn smirked. How disappointed would they be when Isabella's true colors were exposed?

Just outside the company gates, they spotted Margaret Valentine blocking Adrian Valentine's path.

"Adrian! Isabella is your fiancée—you must save her!" Margaret's voice trembled with hysteria.

The moment she learned of her daughter's abduction, panic consumed her. The paternity test arrived that morning, and now this—it had to be the same culprit.

But she couldn't reveal the truth to Adrian. Isabella had to marry into the Valentine family!

Adrian's gaze turned glacial. "When Cassandra was kidnapped, you didn't seem nearly as concerned."

His own sister's peril had barely registered with Margaret. Yet now, she was frantic over an adopted daughter.
